item.title: about
item.description: My training is mostly in biochemistry, though I’m looking to expand my toolkit to attack problem based projects about how organisms work. To that end, I like to think about how nature has evolved molecular pathways and machines, and how we can engineer them to our advantage. I’m always excited to talk about unusual biology; some of my favorite stories of late are about bacterial sociology and altruistic trees. I’m committed to making my science (and hopefully everyone’s, soon enough) open access, and I’m passionate about effective science communication.

item.title: brief CV
item.description: Here are some of the places I’ve done science. View my full CV here. Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2020 - Present) PhD student in the biology department. Deciding on a thesis lab soon! Massachusetts General Hospital (2018-2020) Research technician in the Chao Lab, for the Department of Molecular Biology. I used single particle cryo-electon microscopy to study mitochondrial proteins and helped to get in situ cryo-electron tomography up and running between MIT and MGH.
